seo.title: Best beaches in Positano
seo.description: Expanded beach overview covering Positano, Praiano, Furore, Sorrento, Amalfi, and Capri day trips.

intro: To ensure that you have a great beach day, we have compiled a list of the main beaches available. The list is presented in table format, providing an overview of the features and amenities offered by each beach.

For more information about each beach, click on the name of the beach in the table below. This will take you to our guides, each of which include travel directions and descriptions of the various sections of the beach.

sections.title: How to choose the right beach
body: Positano offers a mix of free pebbled stretches and organised lidos. Lounger prices range from €15 at smaller clubs to €400 at prestige decks like La Scogliera, so decide early whether you want full service or a free towel spot.
Our comparison table groups beaches by town. Each entry lists starting lounger costs, if a free area exists, and quick pros and cons so you can balance sun hours, crowds, and convenience.

sections.title: Positano beaches at a glance
body: Fornillo stays the hostel favourite thanks to its relaxed vibe, two free sections (one tucked away), and beach clubs such as Pupetto, Grassi, Ferdinando, and La Marinella starting around €15. The climb back up is steep, so many walkers cut across to the main beach and ride the bus uphill — check the %LINK:fornilloBeachGuide|Fornillo beach guide% for operator details and free-zone maps.

Spiaggia Grande delivers the postcard view with Positano's cliffside skyline behind the umbrellas. Expect higher prices: L'Incanto starts near €25, while La Scogliera's VIP decks run €100–€400. A public strip sits in the middle, yet most guests prefer Fornillo's calmer scene — follow our %LINK:positanoMainBeachWalkDown|walking directions% or %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusDown|bus guide% to arrive quickly, then use the %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusBack|return bus tips% if you want to skip the climb back.

Arienzo combines long afternoon sun with a dramatic staircase descent. Packages with loungers, lunch, and boat transfers start near €60 and include access to the club's water taxi—ideal because independent access is challenging. Use the %LINK:arienzoBeachClub|Arienzo Beach Club guide% for shuttle timing and booking tips.

Laurito is a compact cove serviced by Da Adolfo (free loungers with a restaurant tab) and Villa Tre Ville (from €30). Sunshine lasts late into the day, but the only easy access is via their shuttle boats; the public section is tiny. For shuttle details and timing, see the %LINK:lauritoBeachGuide|Laurito Beach guide%.

sections.title: Praiano day-trip options
body: Praiano's Gavitella Beach is a sunset haven with a restaurant terrace ideal for aperitivi and dinner. There is no free zone, and the midday heat reflects off the concrete platforms, so aim for late afternoon. Use the %LINK:gavitellaBeachGuide|Gavitella beach guide% for step-by-step access.

Marina di Praia offers a narrow pebble cove framed by fishing boats and cliffs. A modest free section remains alongside lidos—perfect if you want a change of scenery without losing services. See the %LINK:marinaDiPraiaBeaches|Marina di Praia guide% for transport options.

sections.title: Furore's fjord-style cove
body: Fiordo di Furore is the Amalfi Coast's Instagram classic with a stone bridge overhead and cliff-jumping spots. Entry is free and costs stay low, but space is extremely limited so arrive early or visit outside peak hours. Plan the trip with the %LINK:fiordoDiFuroreBeachGuide|Fiordo di Furore beach guide%.

sections.title: Sorrento's Regina Giovanna Bath
body: Regina Giovanna Bath (Bagni della Regina Giovanna) near Sorrento is a natural swimming hole carved into the cliff. It's free to enter, refreshingly cool, and still under the radar compared with Positano's main beaches—pack water shoes and snacks because there are no facilities. Use the %LINK:reginaGiovannaBath|Regina Giovanna Bath guide% for the approach path.

sections.title: Amalfi town beach clubs
body: Amalfi's main Marina Grande beach is lined with clubs such as Stella Maris, Marina Grande Beach Club, Silver Moon, and Bagni Mar di Cobalto. Expect classic lido setups with waiter service, showers, and views of the Duomo backdrop—reserve ahead in high season to secure front-row loungers.

sections.title: Getting to and from the beach
body: For Fornillo and Spiaggia Grande, start from the hostel and descend via Viale Pasitea. If climbing back feels daunting, continue along the waterfront to the main beach and ride the orange internal bus up to Chiesa Nuova, a short walk from Hostel Brikette. Buy tickets at any Tabacchi/newsagent before you need them.

Arienzo and Laurito run private shuttle boats from Spiaggia Grande; confirm the last return sail before committing to a late aperitif. For Praiano, Furore, Sorrento, or Amalfi, follow the linked guides for transport directions, bus schedules, and ferry options.

faqs.question: Which Positano beach is best for budget travellers?
faqs.answer: Fornillo is the most budget-friendly option with loungers starting at €15 and two free sections—one at the far end and a hidden spot near the rocks. The relaxed vibe and lower prices make it a favourite among hostel guests.

faqs.question: Are there any free beaches near Positano?
faqs.answer: Yes. Fornillo has two free zones, Spiaggia Grande has a public strip in the middle, and Fiordo di Furore is entirely free. Regina Giovanna Bath near Sorrento is also free but has no facilities.

faqs.question: How do I get to Arienzo or Laurito beach?
faqs.answer: Both beaches are best reached by shuttle boat from Spiaggia Grande. Arienzo requires descending around 300 stairs if walking, while Laurito has very limited land access. Book a beach club package that includes boat transfer for the easiest experience.

faqs.question: What time should I arrive at the beaches?
faqs.answer: For popular spots like Fornillo and Spiaggia Grande, arrive by 9-10am to secure a good spot on free sections. Fiordo di Furore fills up quickly due to its small size—arrive early or visit outside peak hours. Gavitella is best for late afternoon when the sunset views are spectacular.

faqs.question: How much do beach loungers cost in Positano?
faqs.answer: Prices vary widely. Budget clubs at Fornillo start around €15, while mid-range options at Spiaggia Grande begin near €25. Premium decks like La Scogliera can run €100-€400 for VIP setups. Arienzo packages including loungers, lunch, and boat transfer start near €60.

faqs.question: Can I take a day trip to beaches outside Positano?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Praiano (Gavitella and Marina di Praia), Furore's fjord cove, Sorrento's Regina Giovanna Bath, and Amalfi's Marina Grande are all reachable by SITA bus or ferry. Check each guide for specific transport directions and schedules.

faqs.question: What should I bring to the beach?
faqs.answer: Essential items include reef-safe sunscreen, water shoes (especially for rocky beaches like Regina Giovanna), cash for smaller beach clubs, and a reusable water bottle. If visiting free zones, bring your own towel, shade, and snacks as facilities may be limited.

faqs.question: Which beach has the best sunset views?
faqs.answer: Gavitella in Praiano is renowned for its sunset aperitivi scene—the restaurant terrace offers spectacular views as the sun dips below the horizon. Laurito also enjoys late-day sun due to its position along the coast.
